docs.lead_paragraph: Having counted on Washington for money that may not be delivered, at least 30 states will have to close larger-than-anticipated shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid. Governors and state lawmakers, already facing some of the toughest budgets since the Great Depression, said the repercussions would extend far beyond health care, forcing them to make deep cuts to education, social services and public safety.

headline.main: Medicaid Cut Places States In Budget Bind

docs.abstract: At least 30 states will have to close larger-than-anticipated shortfalls in coming fiscal year unless Congress passes six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid; governors and state lawmakers facing tough budgets say repercussions would extend far beyond health care; some predict outcome would result in huge layoffs for government employees and other workers; Medicaid provision, which would extend assistance first granted in 2009 stimulus package, was considered sure bet by many governors and legislative leaders, who prematurely included money in their budgeting; but under pressure from conservative Democrats to rein in deficit spending, House leaders eliminated $24 billion in aid to states from bill that was approved and forwarded to Senate; Senate plans to take up measure and Majority Leader Harry Reid is said to favor restoring money; photo (M)
docs.snippet: At least 30 states will have to close shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.
